items.title: 4 million guns and counting: Australia's gun debate is heating up
items.description: Straight-pull rapid-fire rifles, social media campaigns, and a looming buyback scheme – Australia's gun debate is reloading.

items.title: PM booed as Sydney's grieving Jewish community marks a week since massacre
items.description: At 6:47pm, one week to the minute after the start of the Bondi Beach terror attack, silence fell across the dusk gathering on the final night of the Jewish festival of light.

items.title: What we know about the Bondi gunmen's mysterious month in the Philippines
items.description: The long shadow of the Bondi shooting has also darkened the coastal southern Philippines, causing deep confusion and stoking long-held anxieties over terrorist groups in the region.

items.title: Doctors turn Ozempic patients away from surgery due to extra risks
items.description: Doctors say they are forced to delay some procedures due to the risk of serious consequences for patients on Ozempic-like drugs.

items.title: As a building company collapses, clients want to know 'where the money went'
items.description: Since 2017, Melbourne building boss Mike Harris has overseen four company collapses. Left behind are clients who have lost their life savings and staff who couldn't pay their mortgages.

items.title: 'Underprepared' England admits it got things wrong in the Ashes
items.description: Losing an Ashes Test series in Australia is nothing new for England, but finally the Bazballers are looking inwards at their own failings after a stirring end to the Adelaide Test.

items.title: Why the contrast between Minns and PM has been stark
items.description: As Sydneysiders paid their respects to the Bondi terror victims, one moment captured the contrast between two Labor leaders and their perceived responses to antisemitism.

items.title: From election triumph to an unthinkable tragedy: How politics shaped 2025
items.description: The ABC's political reporters, commentators and broadcasters reflect on what defined the year in politics.

items.title: Between AI and humanoid robots, we could be at a turning point in history
items.description: What makes the AI-driven stockmarket bubble unique in history is that if it's not a bubble, the impact on humanity could be far more challenging than any previous technology.

items.title: Long-awaited mandatory wine industry code of conduct too late for growers
items.description: After 20 years, three senate inquiries and an independent review, the sale of wine grapes will be regulated by a mandatory code of conduct, but growers say it might be too late.

items.title: Fight to close 'loophole' after DV offender charged interstate while on bail
items.description: Jessica Seage fought for six years for the man who raped her to be convicted. Experts say her experience is a stark example of how perpetrators abuse the system to inflict more pain on their victims.

items.title: Gunmen kill nine, wound 10 in South Africa bar attack
items.description: The incident happened just before 1am local time at a licensed tavern in Johannesburg's Bekkersdal township.

items.title: A Reddit user proved vital in locating the Brown University shooting suspect
items.description: On December 13 a gunman killed two Brown University students and wounded nine others, escaping by foot.

items.title: 'Legal phoenixing' wipes millions in business debt but leaves staff out of pocket
items.description: A digital marketing agency run by a former AFL star has wiped its millions in debt through an insolvency process, only to open under a new ABN days later. Former staff were left without a job and almost $450,000 in unpaid entitlements, but it's within the bounds of the law and leaves taxpayers footing the bill.

items.title: 'I didn't agree to it': Rise of automatic tipping sparks backlash
items.description: Australia's tipping culture is in the spotlight, following reports more businesses are adding automatic tips to diners' bills in response to rising operating costs.

items.title: How well do you remember past Christmas weeks? Test yourself
items.description: We're getting towards the end of the year, but the march of history continues!

items.title: Baker went to jail in 1977 so you can enjoy fresh bread at weekends
items.description: Richard Warby still remembers the day his local community piled into a mini-bus bound for Long Bay Jail to pay a fine and release his father, who was locked up for the bizarre crime of baking bread on a weekend.

items.title: Christmas wish comes true as 6yo Laylah is cancer free
items.description: When six-year-old Laylah-Jane Morton rang the bell at the Queensland Children's Hospital, it marked the end of her chemotherapy treatment for blood cancer — and she had her merry band of eight siblings with her to help her celebrate.

items.title: Retirement dreams shattered after paying $84k for a never-built house
items.description: Multiple people are speaking out about their experience paying too much to a building company for work never delivered.

items.title: How a silly, satirical K-pop hit forever shaped our cultural landscape
items.description: Who'd have guessed a South Korean man doing a goofy horse dance was a recipe for a global phenomenon? Thirteen years after it made YouTube history we revisit the legacy of Psy's Gangnam Style.

items.title: The fight to save Australia's disappearing beaches
items.description: Most Australians live by the beach, but the coastline we have built our lives around is disappearing before our eyes.

items.title: 'A big storm day': Tornadoes possible as wild weather hits Victoria
items.description: Victorians faced intense rainfall, damaging winds and large hailstones after severe storms swept across parts of the state. Emergency services called on road users to drive carefully in dangerous conditions.

items.title: After a million kilometres, stock agent retires LandCruiser 4WD
items.description: A Victorian stock agent's four-wheel drive LandCruiser has reached a rare milestone, as experts say Australians are keeping their cars longer than ever.

items.title: 'Another level of betrayal': Survivors search the Epstein files to find nothing
items.description: Despite giving an FBI interview and victim statement, Epstein survivor Jess Michaels finds no trace of her evidence in the vast trove published online.

items.title: Small regional charity stops thousands of Nepali girls being trafficked
items.description: After hearing harrowing stories of abuse against young Nepalese women and girls, Port Macquarie man Ross Nancarrow wanted to help.
